baseline_groups.claim_summary: Higher UI benefits are associated with higher unemployment rates, with an elasticity of approximately 0.5 in log-log terms. The key finding is that this elasticity varies by age group, with the effect being heterogeneous across the life cycle.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline (with interaction/age structure) has coef 0.508 (positive, SE 0.071, p<0.001). Baseline_pooled (two-way FE) has coef -0.476 (negative, SE 0.074, p<0.001). The sign difference reflects different specifications -- the pooled two-way FE shows negative (higher benefits -> higher unemployment). The paper's primary claim is about heterogeneity in the UI-unemployment elasticity by age, not just the average effect.

global_notes: Paper is 'Optimal Life Cycle Unemployment Insurance' by Michelacci & Ruffo (AER). The specification search covers the CPS panel analysis (Figure 1b and related). Two baseline specs exist: one with age-specific structure (positive coef) and one pooled (negative coef). The key insight is about age heterogeneity: young workers show positive coefficients while older workers show negative. The structural model (optimal UI design) is not covered.
